channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Live Updates: Protesters Rally Before Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
item.description: About 5,000 people protested outside the Capitol against Israel’s conduct of the war in Gaza. Some carried signs calling the Israeli prime minister a “war criminal.” Others chanted “free, free Palestine.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times

item.title: Fatah and Hamas Sign Unity Deal in China, but Deep Divisions Remain
item.description: In a move brokered by China, Fatah and Hamas endorsed a unified government for the West Bank and Gaza, but Palestinians are skeptical that the two parties can put aside their differences.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon, Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Alexandra Stevenson and Thomas Fuller
item.media:description: Foreign Minister Wang Yi, center, of China hosted an event for Mahmoud al-Aloul, left, vice chairman of Fatah, and Mousa Abu Marzouk, a senior member of Hamas, in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: New Zealand Abuse in Care Report Speaks of ‘National Catastrophe’
item.description: The head of a six-year investigation into mistreatment in orphanages, mental health institutions and elsewhere said it found an “unthinkable national catastrophe” unfolding over decades.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: A crowd gathered at Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, for the release of an inquiry’s report into the abuse of children and vulnerable adults in state- and faith-based institutions over decades.

item.title: Ukrainians Are Turning to ‘Death Doulas’ Amid War With Russia
item.description: The work of those who guide people coping with acute grief has grown in importance in war-torn Ukraine, where death has become a daily reality since the Russian invasion.
item.dc:creator: Daria Mitiuk, Constant Méheut and Laura Boushnak
item.media:credit: Laura Boushnak for The New York Times

item.title: Mediterranean Drought Forces a Hard Choice: Who Gets the Water?
item.description: Parts of southern Italy and other countries in the region are experiencing one of their worst droughts in decades. The authorities say they are working to at least save tourism.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Gianni Cipriano

item.title: Paris, City of Light and Shadows, Is Redrawn for the Olympics
item.description: The Games will usher visitors through France’s history, with events at the Grand Palais and Versailles. But, as host, Paris is also becoming a new city.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen and James Hill
item.media:description: An American marching band visits the Eiffel Tower in June. The Paris landmark will loom over beach volleyball matches at the Olympic Games. Many of Paris’s historical sites will host events.

item.title: Ukraine Presses China to Help Seek End to War With Russia
item.description: A visit by the foreign minister of Ukraine to Guangzhou this week signals Kyiv’s desire to involve Beijing in peace talks that China has thus far largely snubbed.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Constant Méheut
item.media:description: In a photo released by Chinese state media, Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba, left, of Ukraine shakes hands with his Chinese counterpart, Wang Yi, before talks in Guangzhou, China, on Wednesday.

item.title: Meet the Woman Leading Venezuela’s Opposition to Maduro
item.description: Spurned by the country’s authoritarian president and even her own colleagues in the opposition, María Corina Machado has built the most significant voter mobilization since Hugo Chávez.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz, Isayen Herrera and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: María Corina Machado campaigning last week in Guanare, Venezuela. Polls show enormous support for her movement ahead of Sunday’s election.

item.title: Kamala Harris’s Indian Heritage Is Deeply Felt if Little Advertised
item.description: Many Indian Americans see Kamala Harris as another example of the diaspora’s success and influence.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris with Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India at the White House last year. At a luncheon, Ms. Harris spoke of her personal connection to India.

item.title: You Can Buy Meat Grown in a Lab in This Country
item.description: Singapore, which subsists on imported food, is looking to secure its future with new ways of feeding its people.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ore Huiying for The New York Times
item.media:description: Huber’s Butchery in Singapore, which is selling lab grown meat.

item.title: Dancers Drop Threat to Strike During Paris Olympics Opening Ceremony
item.description: Organizers avoided disruption by agreeing to give performers on temporary contracts a greater cut of broadcast royalties.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The opening ceremony for the Olympic Games in Paris will take place Friday on and around the Seine River in Paris.

item.title: North Korean Trash Balloons Land on South Korean Leader’s Compound
item.description: Officials found nothing hazardous in the balloons’ payloads, as the North’s slow barrage of airborne garbage showed few signs of letting up.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Yonhap, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Cleaning up the payload of a balloon from North Korea that landed in a Seoul street on Wednesday.

item.title: Salt Lake City Will Host 2034 Winter Olympics
item.description: The Utah capital’s victory was ratified only after Olympic officials won the right to pull the Games if the U.S. authorities undermined the World Anti-Doping Agency.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Tariq Panja
item.media:description: Members of the Salt Lake City 2034 delegation after Wednesday’s vote in Paris.

item.title: When the Paris Olympics Begin, the Seine Is His Stage
item.description: To open the Games, the theater director Thomas Jolly has masterminded a spectacular waterborne ceremony depicting 12 scenes from French history.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Thomas Jolly, artistic director of all four Olympic and Paralympic ceremonies, in Paris. “I don’t have a model to work from,” he said. “It’s creation in the extreme.”

item.title: Hepatitis A and Other Diseases Surge Among Gaza’s Displaced, U.N. Says
item.description: More than 100,000 people are suspected to have contracted hepatitis A, while polio, a disease that has been eradicated in much of the world, is now present there, according to the World Health Organization.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Children walking near stagnant wastewater on their way to a food distribution point in Deir al Balah, in central Gaza, last week.

item.title: Germany Bans Islamic Group, Accusing it of Supporting Hezbollah
item.description: The authorities also searched dozens of properties linked to the Islamic Center Hamburg, which has long faced accusations of being a front for the Iranian government.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Nancy Faeser, Germany’s interior minister, accused the I.Z.H. of promoting Islamic extremism.

item.title: Nepal Plane Crash Kills 18 People After Takeoff
item.description: The pilot of the Saurya Airlines flight, which was departing from Kathmandu, was the only survivor, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Yan Zhuang

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s rally in Wisconsin.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris told supporters in Milwaukee that “the baton is in our hands.”

item.title: Kamala Harris and Some Democrats to Skip Netanyahu’s Address to Congress
item.description: A boycott by some Democrats of the Israeli prime minister’s speech will highlight the deep anger within the party’s base about his conduct of the war against Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after his address to Congress in 2015. Dozens of Democrats boycotted that speech, in which he rebuked a proposed U.S. nuclear agreement with Iran.

item.title: Explosion at Jose Cuervo Tequila Factory in Mexico Kills 5
item.description: The explosion on Tuesday in the city of Tequila, near Guadalajara, killed five workers and left two others wounded, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Castillo and Mike Ives
item.media:description: A fire burning after an explosion at a Jose Cuervo tequila plant in Tequila, Mexico, on Tuesday.

item.title: U.K. Royal Family Gets Financial Boost From Offshore Wind and Palaces
item.description: Profits at the Crown Estate doubled thanks to offshore wind deals, while visitors to royal palaces are almost back to prepandemic levels.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:description: King Charles III and other royals on the balcony of Buckingham Palace after attending the King’s Birthday Parade in London last month.

item.title: Harris’s Views on Israel Are in the Spotlight as Netanyahu Visits Washington
item.description: The vice president will be closely watched this week for signs of her approach to the war in Gaza should she win the White House in November.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris has been seen as more critical of Israel’s war in Gaza than President Biden, but she is not expected to express any differences in policy when she meets with the Israeli prime minister.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: Democrats Unite Behind Kamala Harris
item.description: Plus, the head of the Secret Service resigns.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Kamala Harris at her first campaign rally in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, on Tuesday since taking over the Democratic ticket.

item.title: Macron Rejects Left-Wing Group’s Choice for Prime Minister, Lucie Castets
item.description: The left-wing parties stopped quarreling and tapped a little-known civil servant for the job. But President Emmanuel Macron said he would not appoint anyone until after the Paris Summer Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: A portrait of Lucie Castets was displayed on a screen during President Emmanuel Macron’s interview with France 2 television on Tuesday.

item.title: An Unbending Leader’s Crackdown Rains Carnage on Bangladesh
item.description: Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina’s response to protests has left at least 150 people dead and created the biggest challenge yet to her grip on power.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sheikh Hasina, Bangladesh’s prime minister, at her office in Dhaka last year.

item.title: Landslides Kill 150 in Ethiopia
item.description: A waterlogged hillside above a village gave way, burying several houses in mud. Neighbors and rescue workers who had rushed to help were hit by a second slide.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Kumerra Gemechu
item.media:credit: Gofa Zone Government Communication, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Footage from a video released by the local government shows people standing at the bottom of a landslide that occurred in the Geze district in Ethiopia.

item.title: Reality Show Contestant Apologizes After Eating Protected Bird in New Zealand
item.description: A contestant on the reality show “Race to Survive: New Zealand” killed and ate a weka during filming. The contestant, who said he was hungry, has apologized for “disrespecting New Zealand.”
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Education Images/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: The weka, a flightless bird native to New Zealand, is a protected species.

item.title: Brazilian Art Student Switches Coin at the British Museum With a Fake
item.description: The artist aimed to use sleight of hand to point to what he described as the museum’s problematic legacy of colonial-era acquisitions.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Hurtes
item.media:description: A scan of the original coin being manipulated by the artist.

item.title: Hamas and Fatah Signed a Statement of Unity in China, but Skepticism is High
item.description: A joint statement supports the formation of a government of national consensus. But for many Palestinians, the gathering in the Chinese capital was nothing more than a performance bound for failure.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:description: Mahmoud al-Aloul, the deputy leader of the Fatah party; Wang Yi, China’s foreign minister; and Mousa Abu Marzouk, a senior member of Hamas, in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Noriko Ohara, Voice Actress Known for Nobita in ‘Doraemon,’ Dies at 88
item.description: She starred in “Doraemon” and other animated shows watched by nearly every child in Japan, and her voice became widely recognized.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Netanyahu Seeks Support in U.S. Visit, but Will Find a Nation Distracted
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is to meet President Biden and address Congress this week, swapping one political maelstrom at home for another in Washington.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and President Biden in New York last year.

item.title: Canada Issues Evacuation Order for Jasper National Park as Wildfires Burn in Alberta
item.description: Large blazes in the province have led to the evacuation of thousands of people.
item.dc:creator: Qasim Nauman
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:description: A wildfire on Saturday in British Columbia, which borders Alberta.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Kamala Harris’s first campaign appearance.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Vice President Kamala Harris is closing in on the Democratic nomination. Most of the party’s delegates have now endorsed her.

item.title: Neeraj Chopra Stars in India’s Olympic Dream
item.description: Neeraj Chopra’s triumph in Tokyo inspired athletes across the world’s most populous nation. Now his country is chasing a bigger prize: a chance to host the Games for the first time.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman, Suhasini Raj and Atul Loke
item.media:description: A wall of fame at the home of Neeraj Chopra, the Olympic champion in the javelin, in Khandra, India.

item.title: When Pakistan Tightened a Border, Thousands of Lives Were Upended
item.description: Traders in Chaman have done business in Afghanistan for generations, but that stopped when officials made it much harder to cross.
item.dc:creator: Zia ur-Rehman and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:credit: Saiyna Bashir for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gathered in Chaman, Pakistan, to protest new rules that have effectively closed the border with Afghanistan.

item.title: In Georgia’s Depressed Heartland, Pining for the Soviet Past
item.description: While most Georgians support closer integration with Western Europe, many people in industrial areas that collapsed along with Communism in the 1990s express nostalgia for the old Soviet prosperity.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:credit: Natela Grigalashvili for The New York Times
item.media:description: Davit Jakeli, right, who sells scrap metal from his home, and his neighbor looking out across Kazreti, Georgia, in May.

item.title: How to Bring a Gun to the Olympics (If Your Sport Requires One, That Is)
item.description: For members of the U.S. shooting team, competitions may be the easy part. Just getting to them takes steely nerves and careful planning.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Keh
item.media:credit: David Walter Banks for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sagen Maddalena, 30, an American rifle shooter, expects her luggage to draw special attention whenever she travels to competitions.

item.title: Founder of Kakao, South Korean Tech Giant, Arrested Over K-Pop Deal
item.description: Kim Beom-su, the billionaire behind Kakao, was taken into custody on allegations of stock manipulation during a bidding war over a K-pop agency.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang, Jin Yu Young and John Yoon
item.media:description: The Kakao office at Seongnam, South Korea.

item.title: After Harris Declines, Senator Will Preside at Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress
item.description: An aide to Vice President Kamala Harris said she had a scheduling conflict but would meet with the Israeli prime minister this week.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Benjamin Cardin of Maryland, who is heading into retirement, on Capitol Hill this month. He will preside over Congress on Wednesday during an address by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

item.title: Israel Orders New Evacuation in Gaza as Aid Workers Say Bombing Kills Dozens
item.description: Israeli forces said they struck dozens of sites in Khan Younis where Hamas operated and fired rockets, and they shrank the “humanitarian zone” where civilians had been told to go.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Iyad Abuheweila
item.category: International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies
item.media:description: Palestinians rushed wounded people to Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis in southern Gaza after an Israeli bombardment on Monday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Support Builds for Kamala Harris
item.description: Plus, the head of the Secret Service testified before Congress about the assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Kamala Harris made her first public appearance since President Biden’s exit from the race.

item.title: A U.K. Deportation Plan Cost $900 Million. Only Four People Left.
item.description: Britain’s last Conservative government spent almost a billion dollars on its controversial plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda, the newly appointed minister for immigration said Monday.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Migrants in the English Channel in May.

item.title: Trial Set to Start Next Year in Bombing of U.S.S. Cole
item.description: The judge reserved a courtroom for fall 2025. Seventeen U.S. sailors were killed in the bombing, which was a precursor to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The bombing of the U.S.S. Cole, on Oct. 12, 2000, was seen as a precursor of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

item.title: Russia Sentences Alsu Kurmasheva, American Editor, to a Penal Colony
item.description: Ms. Kurmasheva, a Russian American working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, had been charged in relation to an antiwar book she edited.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Alsu Kurmasheva at a hearing in May. She was convicted of “spreading false information about the Russian Army,” a charge that has been used to silence critics of the invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: At Least 6 Killed at Nursing Home in Croatia
item.description: President Zoran Milanovic called for stricter gun control after an attack that shook Croatia, where mass killings are rare. A suspect was arrested nearby.
item.dc:creator: Joe Orovic and Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:description: Police officers at the scene of a shooting at a nursing home in Daruvar, Croatia, on Monday.

item.title: Israel Risks All-Out War With Hezbollah. A Truce in Gaza May Reduce That Threat.
item.description: After nine months of low-level conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, the risk of all-out war is higher than ever. A cease-fire in Gaza would provide an offramp for both sides, diplomats say.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier with the United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon inspecting a house destroyed last week by an Israeli attack in Yarine, in southern Lebanon.

item.title: Ukraine Strikes Debt Restructuring Deal With Creditors
item.description: The deal with private bondholders will help preserve Kyiv’s limited state budget, which is crucial to fund its military. An agreement to suspend debt payments was to expire on Aug. 1.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: An artillery unit in eastern Ukraine on Friday. The debt restructuring deal will allow Ukraine to spend more money on its military.

item.title: Couple Who Attempted to Cross Atlantic Found Dead in Lifeboat
item.description: James Brett Clibbery and his wife, Sarah Justine Packwood, had left Nova Scotia on June 11, bound for the Azores. The authorities recovered remains believed to be theirs earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: James Brett Clibbery and his wife, Sarah Justine Packwood.

item.title: Paul Watson, Anti-Whaling Activist, Is Detained in Greenland
item.description: Mr. Watson, the founder of the conservation group Sea Shepherd, was arrested when his boat docked in Nuuk. He could face extradition to Japan.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Paul Watson in 2018. He is known for his confrontational tactics in combating whaling.

item.title: Biden Shepherded Europe on Ukraine and NATO. What Happens Now?
item.description: President Biden’s stance on Ukraine was shaped by a deep commitment to America’s trans-Atlantic alliance. Some Europeans fear he may be among the last of his kind.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: President Biden with fellow leaders at the Group of 7 summit in Italy last month.

item.title: China is hosting talks between the two main Palestinian factions, but expectations are low.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: Waving the Fatah emblem during a demonstration in the occupied West Bank city of Hebron in October.

item.title: Netanyahu, Who Clashed With Biden, Prepares for a Delicate Farewell
item.description: The Israeli prime minister could expect a freer hand if Donald J. Trump returns to the presidency. But he must rely on President Biden for another six months.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: President Biden and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in Tel Aviv in October.

item.title: A New Candidate Must Now Defend Biden’s Legacy Abroad
item.description: More than any election in decades, this one will be marked by starkly different approaches to an era of simultaneous confrontations, from China to Russia to the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:description: If Vice President Kamala Harris runs against Donald J. Trump, she will be defending President Biden’s record against Mr. Trump’s radically different interpretation of recent years.

item.title: Heat Waves Are Pounding Egypt, and Often There’s No A.C.
item.description: Daily power cuts have been plaguing Egypt during an extraordinarily hot summer. Now the blackouts may be temporarily suspended, but the damage to confidence in the government has already been done.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Emad Mekay
item.media:description: Shops were closed in Cairo early this month as the government imposed blackouts to save energy.

item.title: The Decathlete Who Picked Up a Gun
item.description: About 500 top-level Ukrainian athletes and coaches have died in the war. Volodymyr Androshchuk promised his loved ones he would make it back.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Oleksandr Chubko

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Serving in the White House “has been the greatest honor of my life,” President Biden said. He said he would complete his term in office.

item.title: World Leaders React to Biden Campaign Decision
item.description: Foreign leaders did not wade into the turmoil of U.S. politics. Many opted instead for statements of empathy that lauded the president’s record.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.media:description: President Biden at the NATO summit in Washington this month. He announced on Sunday that he would not seek re-election.
